pages.text: In ages long past, the brewing of potions was considered a difficult task, as the brews not only needed regular ingredients to manifest an effect, but also special ones that would allow you to create the brew itself. Therefore, the brewing of potions was costly and limited to the amount of capacity ingredients you were able to muster.

Fortunately, it was discovered that crafting cauldrons with a piece of silver would allow to skip such step, thus simplifying the brewing process.$(br2)Should a witch wish to brew a potion, it should firstly have a boiling cauldron, as well as an altar in the nearby vicinity. Once it has both of them, the process starts with the usage of a $(o)$(item)$(t:Netherwart...)wart from the depths of the burning hells$(/t)$(), which should be thrown into the boiling water.

An ingredient should then follow.$(br2)From here, the witch can choose to augment the effect caused by the ingredient, or to add further ingredients.$(br2)In order to do the first, a witch can add $(l:potion_brewing/potion_modifiers)$(o)$(item)specific items$() to the brew, $(o)$(thing)following the effect they want to modify$(). $(br2)In order to add more effects, one can just add new ingredients.

Do note that both brew effect modification and multiple effects can coexist, but only if the ingredients are added in the correct order (that is, the augments you wish to add to the prior ingredient would go first, followed by the next ingredient, and so on and so forth).$(br2)Finally, in order to collect the brew, a witch would use one of the different $(l:potion_brewing/potion_containers)$(o)$(item)vessels$() used to store them (which determines how the potion will

manifest in world -i.e: drank, splash...). $(br2)To do so, however, the witch must channel some energy (either from itself or from a nearby altar) into the silver contained in the cauldron. $(br2)In this regard, keep in mind that $(o)$(thing)the more complex the potion is, the more magic it will require...
